conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, analyze their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The distance between the two objects is determined by the difference in their positions, found by calculating the area under each velocity-time graph.
Object A has a constant velocity, represented by a straight line.
Object B has a velocity that changes over time, represented by a curve.
The position of an object at any time t is given by the area under its velocity-time graph from t = 0 to t.
The distance between the two objects at any time t is the absolute difference between the areas under the two graphs up to that time.
The maximum separation occurs when the difference in the areas under the two graphs is the greatest.
From t = 0 to t1, object B is moving slower than object A, so the distance between them increases.
At t1, object B starts to move faster than object A, so the distance between them starts to decrease.
The maximum separation occurs at t1, just before object B starts to catch up to object A.
The two objects are farthest apart at time t1.
